_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: 90% of the equipment is inside the facility

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY 



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION POLICIES



The facility has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the Ammonia Refrigeration System. The facility policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent the foreseeable release of regulated substances. The number of full time equivalent employees on site is zero, as the facility is vacant and there are no tenants occupying the building. 



HAZARD ASSESSMENT/OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS



The Off-site Consequence Analysis must be reviewed every five years or within six months of process changes or other changes that may significantly affect the results of the Off-site Consequence Analysis.



Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary

Scenario Description: Per the EPA RMP Regulations, one worst-case release scenario has been defined for the Ammonia Refrigeration System. A summary of the results can be located in the Worst Case Scenario section of this RMP submittal. 



Alternative Release Scenario Results Summary

Scenario Description: Per the EPA RMP Regulations, one alternative-case release scenario has been defined for the Ammonia Refrigeration System. A summary of the results can be located in the Alternative Release Scenario section of this RMP submittal.



Risk Considerations

Although the storage and use of anhydrous ammonia has inherent potential risks and the release scenarios can potentially reach sensitive populations within the community, the facility has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst case type of event non-credible.  It should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an event, which furth

er makes the worst case type of event non-credible. In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with an anhydrous ammonia release.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM



As part of the implementation of EPA RMP Program 3, key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by the facility to manage process safety issues associated with the use of anhydrous ammonia. Prevention Program 3 elements are listed below:

?    Process Safety Information (PSI)

?    Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)

?    Operating Procedures (OP)

?    Training (TRN)

?    Mechanical Integrity (MI)

?    Management of Change (MOC)

?    Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR)

?    Compliance Audits (CA)

?    Incident Investigation (II)

?    Employee Participation (EP)

?    Hot Work Permit (HWP)

?    Contractors (CON)



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no EPA RMP-applicable releases of anhydrous ammonia at the facility in at least the past five (5) years.



EXTERNAL EVENTS ANALYSIS



During the May 2014 PHA, a broad list of external events was considered by the Team. General events external to the plant that can conceivably cause a release of anhydrous ammonia were addressed. The External Events that were considered credible include, but are not limited to, an act of nature (earthquake, thunderstorm, lightning, high winds, snowstorm, tornadoes, aircraft impact, external fire, and human error/mis-operation. The magnitudes of the external events considered are detailed within the PHA Worksheets and were qualitatively risk-ranked by the PHA Team. General events external to the plant that can conceivably cause a release of anhydrous ammonia were addressed by the Process Hazard Analysis. This technical document can be found in the PSM/CalARP/RMP Program 3 Compliance Workbook.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM 



The facility is included in the wr

itten Community Emergency Response Plan (ERP) and has an Emergency Action Plan in place. Furthermore, the facility has procedures in place to evacuate the facility and notify responders when there is a need for response, located onsite.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The PHA study has been conducted to examine mitigation measures to improve safety at the facility. Planned changes to improve safety are listed as recommendations in the May 2014 PHA Report. Any outstanding recommendations will be addressed by May 2015.
